Expectation1: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation1: The experiment is reserved during a limited window when specialized instruments are available.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my computer screen, the lab reservation confirmation glaring back at me. Tomorrow, I’d finally have access to the spectrometer—an opportunity that came only once every few months. My team was counting on me to run the experiment, collect the data, and move our research forward. The pressure was immense; missing this window would set us back for weeks, maybe months. But as I glanced at the calendar, my heart sank. Tomorrow was Sunday. I’d promised my family I’d go to church with them, and I’d promised myself I’d honor the Sabbath, keeping it as a day of rest and worship. My faith taught me to put God first, to trust that work could wait. Yet, the scientist in me knew how rare this chance was, how much depended on my actions. I felt torn, the weight of my colleagues’ expectations pressing against the quiet conviction in my soul. I closed my eyes, wrestling with the impossible choice, feeling the tension between my devotion to science and my commitment to my faith.
